title: Wednesday, 25th November, 2015

11:04 am
PM

Gauging the risks of balance sheet dislocation in Brazil
The country's deepest recession in the past 25 years raises the risk of unexpected
events, such as balance sheet dislocation for corporates and households. Leverage
today is much higher than it was during previous crises, which amplifies credit
concerns. We see NPLs deteriorating to 4.2% (from 3.1% now) – close to the 2008/09
levels – and jumping to 4.8% under a stress scenario (USD/BRL at 5.50 and GDP
growth at -3.9% in 2016). Nonetheless, we see the likelihood of systemic risk in the
banking system as low.
Contingent liability from public banks is a risk
A large portion of credit growth has come from public sector banks, which could be a
direct liability for the government at a time when the fiscal accounts are not in good
shape. Provisions on private banks increased more than proportionally to the NPL rise,
which wasn't the case at state-owned banks. Also, exposure to SMEs is larger at stateowned
banks than at private banks. Bottom-up, asset quality has so far held up
relatively well, but we are beginning to see a divergence in delinquency trends between
public and private banks.

PM

Sharp NPL rise does not necessarily mean larger provisioning burden
For the four Brazilian banks under our equities coverage, aggregated excess provisions
of R$22.5bn at 3Q15 more than exceeded the incremental rise in NPLs in our statistical
model’s base case but fall short of incremental NPLs in the stress scenario. We think
Itau appears to be best placed to absorb additional credit risk; in contrast, our analysis
suggests BB could have a provisioning shortfall ranging from R$1.7-4.9bn (base case -
stress case).
Upside scenario: Better NPL cycle could lift 2016 earnings by 24%
In the scenario that growth surprises positively and asset quality deteriorates less than
feared, we believe there is potential for banks to reverse excess provisions next year. In
this scenario, aggregated earnings would rise by 23.8% with ROE rising to 20.5% or by
360bp, while the Tier 1 ratio would increase by 50bp (raising the potential for
enhanced capital deployment).
BRL depreciation could also be a problem for external debt
Rising external indebtedness, sharp BRL depreciation, incomplete hedging, and the
large amount of debt coming due before 2017 increase the chances of external
corporate credit problems. Non-financial corporates with more risk are Petrobras, Oi
and Vale, in our view. Additionally, state-owned banks might have to amply provide
liquidity to troubled corporates, which only postpones capital concerns and increases
the parties at risk, in our view.

BE

Quite a lead paragraph though.

BE

George Osborne will on Wednesday announce “the biggest housebuilding programme since the 1970s”, in an Autumn Statement intended to repair relations with the swaths of the electorate alienated by his attempted £4.4bn raid on their tax credits.

PM

But there's no one to build the stuff

PM

Construction sector has run out of workers

BE

Hm. This is, of course, cognitive dissonance corner.

BE

So the Treasury's throwing £2.3bn at the sector to build 200,000 "starter homes", to be sold at a 20% discount to market value

11:08 am
BE

With a further £4bn on shared ownership homes.

BE

But as always with Lobby-based pre-news briefings, it's difficult to get a handle on what's actually being announced.

PM

indeed

11:08 am
BE

There's always a counterweight. We'll find out what it is around 4pm, probably.

BE

Whichever way, it seems we market participants are celebrating the promise of state-subsidised housebuilding volume.

BE

And choosing for a moment to ignore the brake the BOE will have to apply to the mortgage market.

11:09 am
BE

As in, adding a countercyclical buffer.

BE

And introducing stress tests from 2016 that actually test stress.

BE

And rejigging RWA calculations to treat buy-to-let as commercial lending, which it is, rather than consumer lending, which it's not.

11:10 am
BE

None of which is good for housebuilders. It's disastrous for small banks, but it's not great for housebuilders either.

PM

hmm

BE

What's clear, as of today, is that forecasts don't move. Here's Caz.

11:10 am
BE

The headline policy isn’t new, the precise commitment to direct funding is. It is not currently clear if these will replace the requirement to build social housing as part of new developments. From the initial info being reported this morning and conversations we have had with housebuilders over the last few months, we do not currently expect a material impact on either earnings or the housing market.

BE

And Deutsche Bank, from last week.

BE

Through Q2 15 the number of new home completions in England dipped 2% to c.35,000. With a target of 1m new homes over the life of the Parliament (ie approx 200,000 pa, 50,000 per quarter) this suggests a focus on the housing market and housebuilding will remain. In the last budget, the UK housebuilding stocks fell approx 5% reflecting market concern on the impact of changes in buy-to-let tax relief. This time we believe any impact may be more moderate.

11:11 am
BE

(@Mouselet: they provide a key funding support for buy-to-let parasites.)

BE

5 key policies and issues in the sector
Help to Buy (shared equity). Under this programme the government takes a 20% stake in any home bought under the scheme (max price £600,000). This product has been extended to 2020 to finance a further 120,000 new-build transactions (in addition to the 74,000 targeted in the original scheme).
Starter homes: In October the Govt announced that developers will have the choice of providing Starter homes instead of the current affordable requirement for Social Rent. Starter homes will be sold at a 20% discount to market price (the price capped at £250K for UK, £450K London) with the government targeting 200,000 starter homes by 2020. Key will be the nuts and bolts of the policy, including how the Starter Homes will impact other Section 106 costs (ie the cost of gaining planning) and also how Local Authorities will be incentivized (either stick or carrot) to comply.
Planning. In its July planning update the govt included the threat of “tougher action to ensure that local authorities are using their powers to get local plans in place” (although it remains unclear how this would be done). The Govt also announced plans to bring forward proposals to “streamline the length and process of local plans”, as well as a reduction net regulation.
Buy to let: In its last Statement the govt announced a reduction in the tax deductibility of buy to let mortgage payments at the higher tax levels (40%, 45%) to basic rate taxation levels (20%), over a 4 year period from 2017, as well as the replacement of the existing 10% wear and tear tax relief on buy to let properties by a new relief which allows landlords to deduct the actual cost of replacing furnishings. Within this Statement we believe the Chancellor may refer to brining Buy to Let mortgages under the MMR in April 2016. While we believe this to be positive in the long term, it could add to sector volatility in Q2 16.
Stamp Duty. With both RICS and the Council of Mortgage Lending warning that the lack of supply of homes is pushing up house prices, within this Statement we believe the Govt has an opportunity to make adjustments to Stamp Duty (which saw the slab structured tax replaced with a new progressive system at the end of last year). While we don’t see wholesale changes, we believe adding a few extra bands in around the £925K price level to ease the step up in tax could encourage greater availability of homes at the top end of the market, so greater facilitating housing chains for the range of prices.

BE

So, yeah, don't know why housebuilders are up today. Logic says they shouldn't be.

11:12 am
BE

But perhaps the lesson from history is that we shouldn't put too much reliance on logic when it comes to housing.

PM

I sense this irritates the hell out of you Bryce

BE

It does. I find the housebuilders, as a sector, systemically broken.

But that was nearly politics, which we don't do here. So let's move on.

The chancellor is also expected to back a £250m-plus Northern Powerhouse Investment fund to finance businesses over the next five years. It will combine European Union regional cash with a top-up from Whitehall. The so-called “Jeremie” funds from the EU provided £360m of loans and equity finance between 2010-15 in three northern regions.
While the north-west and Yorkshire are set to combine their 2016-20 funds under the aegis of the state-owned British Business Bank, the north-east is expected to retain a separate £160m fund.

BE

BE

 Cost and dividend cuts might not stop cash burn altogether
 Big strategic changes are complicated; strong liquidity yields
false security and may delay change until it's too late
 Risk of more pain ahead, lacking clarity on a long-term
solution. We cut our target price to GBP4.10 (from GBP7.70)

BE

First, cut the dividend. Potentially reinstate at a later date on payout ratio basis
We think, before further capex cuts, Anglo would burn at least USD2.7bn in 2016 on spot
to maintain the dividend. We see high likelihood of a zeroed dividend (now in our
numbers), which saves USD1.1bn cash annually. Should Anglo reinstate the dividend at
a later stage, with think a payout ratio (with provision for specials) is more prudent.

11:19 am
PM

Four quid target price!?!

BE

Further cost cuts likely in Dec 8th update, but we question if they’re enough
We see scope for capex to be reduced to c.USD2.7bn post 2016 and USD3.3bn in 2016
(current guidance USD3.6-3.9bn). We think corporate costs and overheads are the key
area of viable opex cuts, although not a new target area. Any further cost cut efforts at
operations will only go some way to offset greater than 5% South African inflation, in our view.

PM

blimey

11:19 am
BE

Without price recovery, Anglo still burns cash. Liquidity a double-edged sword
We estimate Anglo will still burn USD1.6bn in annual cash flow post expected opex,
capex and divi cuts on spot. Liquidity remains comfortable (greater than USD16.6bn at H1’15 post
Tarmac disposal proceeds) with no major covenants at the parent level. However, the
lack of imminent balance sheet issues may also delay potential structural changes.

BE

Bigger strategy considerations: disposals, subsidiary pressures and government
Niobium and phosphates disposals are likely to be challenging in today’s market. Kumba
and Amplats may come under pressure if iron ore and platinum don’t improve, although at
that point we think Anglo’s relative balance sheet strength may place it at a disadvantage
in potential strategic discussions with the South African government. Partial IPO of the
diamonds business remains a long-term positive potential catalyst, although timing is key
(and it’s not now, in our view). We downgrade to Reduce (from Hold), anticipating more
near-term pain and without clarity on a long-term resolution to reverse potential cash
burn. We also cut EBITDA estimates 4-18% over the 2015e-17e period, reflecting weaker
diamond and industrial mineral prices, alongside weaker earnings power elsewhere.

BE

Yeah, 410p target. But how do you value Anglo? Where do you start?

11:20 am
BE

Did you catch Martin Rapaport calling for the head of the head of De Beers overnight?

PM

BE

11:21 am
BE

http://www.mineweb...ubble-bust-part-1/

BE

PM

11:22 am
PM

PM

BE

That's him. His point is that rough prices are higher than polished prices, which for De Beers is utterly nuts.

11:22 am
BE

And De Beers CEO Philippe Mellier is destroying the business as a result.

BE

Because the diamond supply chain's quite small and works on long-term relationships to keep the plates spinning. Rip off the cutters with inflated rough prices and you're destroying any goodwill you may previously have had.

BE

Anyway, the other Anglo note this morning is from Goldman.

11:24 am
PM

What are they saying?

PM

Similar?

BE

Yup, albeit less aggressively phrased. Sector wide.

11:25 am
BE

Investor focus is squarely on two issues: (1) will current dividends be
maintained? and (2) are balance sheets safe at spot commodity prices?
With Glencore having suspended its dividend and taking measures to
shore up its balance sheet, attention will likely be on Anglo and Rio, and
how their respective management teams are thinking about these issues.

BE

Anglo American: Focus on dividend cut, balance sheet & diamonds
We expect Anglo to change from a progressive dividend policy to a payout
ratio with its FY2015 results, as a means of limiting cash outflows. On our
estimates, 2016-17E DPS will fall from US85c to US25c/27c, saving Anglo
c.US$800 mn pa in cashflow. We see the second focus as the balance sheet
and expect management to communicate that it does not need to issue
equity, believing it has sufficient liquidity to weather a potential credit
rating downgrade. We expect diamonds to be the focus of operational
discussions given the weakness in end markets in 2015. We cut our
estimates and price target for Anglo to reflect lower diamond prices.

BE

Rio Tinto: Focus on aluminium may highlight downside
Rio’s capital markets day is focused solely on aluminium: this will give
investors access to Alfredo Barrios, Chief Executive Aluminium, and allow
an update on the Kitimat smelter and the South of Embley bauxite project.
We expect no major announcement from Rio until its 2015 results. We
revise our estimates for Rio to reflect its 3Q production report.

11:25 am
BE

Glencore: The plan is known, looking to execution
We expect an update on the progress of the debt reduction plan laid out on
September 7. However, with commodity prices continuing to hit multi-year
lows, there is renewed concern about the cash-generating ability of the
industrial portfolio. The call might confirm a potential gold streaming deal
at Collahuasi, or the sale of part of the agricultural marketing business.

Rio Tinto PLC (RIO:LSE): Last: 2,244, down 30.5 (-1.34%), High: 2,292, Low: 2,240, Volume: 1.33m
Glencore PLC (GLEN:LSE): Last: 91.80, down 2.18 (-2.32%), High: 95.66, Low: 91.80, Volume: 19.65m

BE

(Bloomberg) -- Ophir Energy Plc, the U.K. oil and gas
explorer active in Africa, has received informal takeover and
merger interest from several parties as a slump in crude oil
prices forces independent operators to consolidate, according to
people with knowledge of the matter.

earlier this year, has attracted interest from both companies
and financial investors, the people said, asking not to be
identified as the information is private. The company, which has
a market value of about 615 million pounds ($928 million), is
evaluating the proposals but deliberations are at an early stage
and it may decide against a deal, the people said.

BE

So, yeah, Ophir has a funding gap on the Fortuna project and is talking to anyone and everyone about it.

BE

Post the dry well the other day, it's not entirely surprising that those talks might encompass a buyout of the whole lot.

11:30 am
BE

Think Ophir needs $640m to reach first gas from Fortuna.

BE

Against a market cap of slightly less than £600m at today's open.

PM

BE

As for Genel ..............

11:33 am
PM

Which surprised me

Genel Energy PLC (GENL:LSE): Last: 258.00, up 3 (+1.18%), High: 268.50, Low: 254.75, Volume: 1.21m
BE

Our understanding is that the Sky report is accurate but very, very, very, very, very early stage.

11:34 am
PM

http://news.sky.co...w-age-merger-talks

BE

As in, they've had talks. But to suggest those talks put them on the cusp of a merger would be rather jumping the gun.

PM

http://www.newafricanglobalenergy.com/

11:35 am
BE

Sky says they're of similar size, so it'd be a straight merger to diversify.

BE

And bringing Genel back into Africa, which might be fun given previous adventures.

BE

Cazenove sees logic in it.

11:36 am
BE

Rationale for Genel. From a Genel perspective, it would provide a more diverse production base, with lower risk to revenues, an issue which has clearly impacted its market rating. It would also add barrels that are easier to finance (via RBL or RCF type bank loans) for growth. It would likely make Genel the largest reserve holder in European E&P.
New Age has a portfolio that overlaps in several regions – Kurdistan, Morocco, Ethiopia. Judging from New Age’s website, it has multiple years of growth and a decent exploration hopper.

BE

Rationale for New Age. From a New Age perspective, a deal would be a way of publically listing the business without a formal IPO process that would likely be very difficult given the current market backdrop. A merger with listed Genel could provide a potential exit route for some New Age shareholders and, of course, a public market valuation, which private equity looks for. One of Genel’s key assets is its seasoned UK listing, in our view.

BE

Questions to answer ahead of a possible merger. 1) Dilution risk – Clearly the structure of the deal is important. From our perspective Genel shares are trading at a steep discount to NAV, meaning it could be NAV dilutive to do a paper deal of size (assuming an all equity exchange).
Such dilution could be reduced if Genel does not pay a premium – arguably New Age should pay the premium given access to Genel’s UK listing. 2) Valuation – What is New Age’s fair value? We do not have a good line of sight on reserves (New Age website cites 861 mmboe 2P +2C), or production (is early stage in the KRI and Congo is likely around 5-10 kbopd currently). 3) Balance sheet – New Age does not have publically traded debt, but it has some convertible debt. 4) Growth profile – New Age’s website cites 5 development projects, of which 3 are LNG developments. We do not know how much capex needs to be deployed to achieve this growth and how much of this growth is still unfunded. Africa has not been a happy experience for Genel shareholders given an expensive and ultimately unsuccessful exploration campaign.

11:37 am
BE

For safety's sake we should note that New Age is PE-owned

BE

Kerogen Capital is the largest shareholder.

BE

And is managed largely by ex Premier Oil people.

11:38 am
PM

Portfolio here: http://www.newafri....com/Our_portfolio

BE

Caz takes a wild stab at valuation.

BE

Potential valuation. Given we have no information on capital structure, portfolio growth and committed and anticipated future capital investment, we are partially sighted. We therefore look at reserves and resources held by the two companies. At Y/E 2014, Genel reported 429 mmbo 2P reserves and 1,460 mmbo 2P + 2C reserves and resources (rising close to 2,600 mmboe if Miran and Bina Bawi gas resources are included). This compares with New Age which, according to Steve Lowden’s biography on the Oil and Gas Council website, has around 450 mmboe 2P reserves and, according to the company website, has 861 mmboe 2P + 2C reserves and resources. On a YE14 basis, Genel tradeson a 2P + 2C reserve multiple of $0.88 per boe. On this multiple, New Age would have an implied EV of $760m vs. Genel $1,290m. Genel trades on a 2P only multiple of $3 per boe. On this multiple, New Age would have an implied EV of $1,350m. If we take a simple mean of these two figures, New Age has an implied EV of $1,055m. If we assume 20% of this is debt, the implied equity value is $844m. At Genel’s current share price of 255p, this implies an issuance of 219m new Genel shares vs.278m currently in issue, an increase of almost 80%.

11:39 am
BE

But as we say, it all feels much more early stage than that. And given the lack of statement this morning, may be currently pens down.

undefined
11:45 am
BE

Shire requested, though in truth not much to add to the Reuters story overnight.

BE

Saying Shire is working on sweetening its BXLT bid with a sliver of cash.

PM

(And before anyone asks -- no, we have no further news on the supposed bid for Radius. I told you you were on your own on that one...)

11:46 am
BE

The fact that Shire's still working on a sweetened bid for BXLT is rather stating the obvious.

BE

If it wasn't, it would have to have told us.

BE

And Shire management has been very vocal about avoiding overpaying, being able to walk away, having other fish in the sea, etc.

11:48 am
BE

One has to wonder whether today's 3% share price move will help focus management's mind on that risk. Investors clearly worried about the price.

BE

Leerink analysts, less so.

BE

with a revised bid that includes cash, we
believe (1) this approach is feasible – based on our checks with a
MEDACorp corporate M&A specialist, SHPG can offer cash as long
as BXLT gets at least 40-50% of transaction cost in equity, maintaining
continuity of interest requirements; (2) financially, the deal is considerably
more attractive if SHPG can partially finance with debt, see our scenario
analysis; (3) if the only changes in revised bid are financing mix, then
the price range appears within acceptable comps and we see the deal
as financially attractive somewhat offset by questions as to strategic fit
and some concerns around competitor headwinds to BXLT's hemophilia
business. This note addresses speculative subject matter & there remain
numerous obstacles to a SHPG-BXLT deal. Maintain OP & $239 PT.

11:49 am
BE

Investor controversies around BXLT deal include structural
impediments & strategic fit. One critical question is whether IRC
Section 355(a), which governs tax-free spin-outs, allows SHPG to now
(4.5 mo post spin) revise its original bid to include cash and how much
cash is acceptable. Per the BAX (MP)-BXLT tax matters agreement,
BXLT cannot be acquired unless there is an unqualified opinion (known
as a “will opinion") that conveys a high level of confidence that the
proposed BXLT acquisition will not trigger any tax problems. We believe
it is unlikely SHPG would be moving forward with cash/stock bid absent
a will opinion from a major accounting firm, which the specialist believes
carries ~90-95% odds of success. While the strategic fit of BXLT isn't
perfect, we do see some synergy between rare disease infrastructure
and view the proposed price (~5.5x EV/S vs. 7-9x for comps) as fairly
reflecting some of the competitive headwinds to BXLT's hemophilia biz.

BE

Specialist feedback suggests SHPG unlikely to trigger tax
penalties by incorporating cash into its bid. MEDACorp specialist
believes SHPG’s ability to use cash comes down to two issues: (1) if
there was a strong business rationale for splitting apart BAX-BXLT and
SHPG didn’t negotiate with BAX pre-spin, then SHPG hasn’t created
an issue wherein BXLT can be deemed a “device” for avoiding tax on
earnings distribution; (2) if BXLT gets 30-50% of the deal financed in
stock, then continuity of interest requirements are satisfied. Assuming
30-50% of the deal is financed with debt, we forecast BXLT being 10-20%
accretive to non-GAAP earnings.

BE

And speaking personally, if we could get some kind of resolution soon on BXLT that'd be very nice.

PM

3. UK divis may disappoint more than Eurozone – contrary to consensus – as stress tests are increasingly the gate on payouts. Below consensus for BARC, LLOY, STAN. Ahead for Natixis, KBC, ISP, UBS.
4. Fears of a new wave of regulations ("Basel IV") could be overstated as policy makers re-assess impact of regulations on the economy. Rather, local macro-prudential rules in UK, Neths, Swiss, & Sweden pose the key risks. Prefer French (BNP, Natixis); Nordics, BARC more disadvantaged.
5. Market set to be positively surprised by a more aggressive sell down of non-core assets prompted by ECB-led risk budgeting, stress tests and new teams. But execution to take out costs will be key. Positive surprises for Unicredit, CS possible.
6. Rising Brexit fears may prove a bigger risk to valuations of UK asset managers than UK banks. Risks for Schroders, Aberdeen, Henderson.
7. SWF redemptions may be a more material risk than retail bond mutual funds – but mutual fund stress tests still likely on concerns on corporate bond market liquidity. Risks for Aberdeen, Ashmore.
8. Banks will launch many pilots & form partnerships - particularly around P2P & Roboadvisers - given anxiety that digital disruptors will skim the cream of banks' profits & concerns on re-engineering legacy systems.
9. Cross-border Eurozone M&A should disappoint. Banking markets could become more not less balkanised due to SSM, US IHC and complexity. Challenging for DB. Capital markets union more promising.
10. Investors may start to reward European banks for being lower risk, helping beta fall further and boosting valuation of divi payers. Prefer those where we're ahead on divis most.

BE

Spangel calls the update "confused," which is politer than necessary.

BE

While nothing new has been disclosed in the Chairman’s statement today, it is a succinct summary of the progress that the Company has made to date and its immediate future. However, there is a tone of caution in some of the language which is understandable given the uncertainty surrounding the status of its JV partner and the outstanding cash calls, we expect the Company to be able to resolve the issues.

Of more concern, is the use of the phrase “anticipate that these wells will be commercially viable” when talking about the valorisation of what has already been classed as Reserves. If there is technical uncertainty they are Contingent Resources, the wells should be termed appraisal wells. If the uncertainty flows from the current situation with the JV partner, then this needs to made clearer, and the Reserves are indeed Reserves.

While we believe that today’s language is confused and will lead to uncertainty, we believe that the outlook for the Company remains positive, and the gas market in India, while woefully mismanaged in the main by the government, in Gujarat at least, free market pricing is a closer reality than elsewhere in India.
